official-title.#text:
To establish a Maritime Goods Movement User Fee and provide grants for international maritime cargo
			 improvements and for other purposes.

committee-name.#tail: , and in addition to the Committee on

, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such
			 provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Maritime Goods Movement Act for the 21st Century
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Maritime Goods Movement Act for the 21st Century

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the
In this Act:
The term
means—

any cargo transported on a commercial vessel, including passengers transported for compensation or
			 hire; and
international maritime cargo; and
does not include—

bunker fuel, ship’s stores, sea stores, or the legitimate equipment necessary to the operation of a
			 vessel; or
fish or other aquatic animal life caught and not previously landed on shore.
The term
means any vessel used—
in transporting cargo by water for compensation or hire; or
in transporting cargo by water in the business of the owner, lessee, or operator of the vessel; and

does not include any ferry engaged primarily in the ferrying of passengers (including their
			 vehicles) between points within the United States, or between the United
			 States and contiguous countries.

term.#tail:
means any vessel which arrives in the United States on a regular schedule during its operating
			 season at intervals of at least once each business day.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail:
means any cargo moved by ship that is imported directly into the United States from a point
			 outside the United States, including—

text.#text: The term
cargo that arrives in the United States by ship; or

cargo that is unloaded in an intermediate country and arrives in the United States by another form
			 of transit without being altered in any manner in the intermediate
			 country.

term.#tail: means a port at which not more than 1,000,000 tons of cargo is transported each calendar year.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: means a place where commercial cargo enters the United States.

text.#text: The term
is not an inland waterway; and
is open to public navigation.

header.#text: Establishment of Maritime Goods Movement User Fee

text.#text:
Except as otherwise provided in this section, there is imposed a Maritime Goods Movement User Fee
			 on all commercial cargo—
unloaded from or loaded on a commercial vessel at a port; or
that enters the United States at a point of entry.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
beginning on October 1 of the first fiscal year beginning after the date
			 of the enactment of this Act.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Maritime Goods Movement Act for the 21st Century/s:3/ss:a/p:1

text.#text: The Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed on commercial cargo under

The amount of the Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be an amount equal to 0.125 percent of the
			 value of the commercial cargo.
The Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be collected by
The Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed on commercial cargo at the time—

the commercial cargo is unloaded from or loaded on a commercial vessel at a port in the United
			 States; or
the commercial cargo enters the United States at a point of entry.

No Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed under this section on any export of the United
			 States.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
(relating to tax on fuels used in commercial
			 transportation on inland waterways).
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
section 4042 of the
			 Internal Revenue Code of 1986
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Internal Revenue Code of 1986/s:4042

text.#text:
No Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed under this section with respect to the loading
			 or unloading of any cargo on or from a vessel if any fuel of such vessel
			 has been (or will be) subject to the tax imposed by

header.#text:
Coordination of fee where transportation subject to tax imposed under 4042 of the Internal Revenue
			 Code
Special rule for Alaska, Hawaii, and possessions

text.#text: No Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed on—

cargo loaded on a vessel in Alaska, Hawaii, or any possession of the United States for
			 transportation to the United States mainland, Alaska, Hawaii, or such a
			 possession for ultimate use or consumption in the United States mainland,
			 Alaska, Hawaii, or such a possession;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: or
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Maritime Goods Movement Act for the 21st Century/s:3/ss:g/p:1/sp:A

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
in Alaska, Hawaii, or any possession of
			 the United States, or in the United States mainland, respectively; or
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Maritime Goods Movement Act for the 21st Century/s:3/ss:g/p:1/sp:B

text.#text: the unloading of cargo described in

cargo loaded on a vessel in Alaska, Hawaii, or a possession of the United States and unloaded in
			 the State or possession in which loaded, or passengers transported on
			 United States flag vessels operating solely within the State waters of
			 Alaska or Hawaii and adjacent international waters.

term.#tail: does not include crude oil with respect to Alaska.

text.#text: For purposes of this subsection, the term

term.#tail: means the continental United States (not including Alaska).

text.#text: For purposes of this section, the term
Except as provided by regulations:
The Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed on the same commercial cargo only 1 time.

Under regulations, no Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed on the mere movement of
			 commercial cargo within a port.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Maritime Goods Movement Act for the 21st Century/s:3/ss:g/p:2

term.#tail: does not include any item not treated as cargo under

text.#text:
Only 1 Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed on cargo (moving under a single bill of
			 lading) which is unloaded from one vessel and loaded onto another vessel
			 at any port in the United States for relay to or from any port in Alaska,
			 Hawaii, or any possession of the United States. For purposes of this
			 paragraph, the term

No Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed on the United States or any agency or
			 instrumentality thereof.

No Maritime Goods Movement User Fee shall be imposed on any nonprofit organization or cooperative
			 for cargo which is owned or financed by such nonprofit organization or
			 cooperative and which is certified by the U.S. Customs and Border
			 Protection as intended for use in humanitarian or development assistance
			 overseas.

header.#text: Exemption for humanitarian and development assistance cargos

text.#text:
No fee may be collected under this section except to the extent that the expenditure of the fee to
			 pay the costs of activities and services for which the fee is imposed is
			 provided for in advance in an appropriations Act.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , any fee collected under this section—

header.#text: Competitive grant program for goods movement
Competitive Grant Program for Goods Movement

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: in consultation with the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Assistant Secretary
			 of the Army for Civil Works
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works

text.#text: There is established a Competitive Grant Program for Goods Movement to be administered by the

The purpose of the Competitive Grant Program for Goods Movement is to provide financial assistance
			 for capital investments that improve the efficiency of the transportation
			 system of the United States to move international maritime cargo.
For each fiscal year, there shall be no less than—
3 grantees that are super donor ports; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Maritime Goods Movement Act for the 21st Century/s:5/ss:d

text.#text: 3 grantees that are eligible entities under

The Federal cost share of a project awarded a grant under this section shall be no more than 50
			 percent of the total cost.

A grant under this section may only be awarded to a State or local government entity, including a
			 port authority.
A grant awarded under this section may be used for the following:

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is authorized to make, including environmental remediation and
			 habitat mitigation if certified by the

to improve the
			 movement of international maritime cargo.
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Assistant Secretary of the Army for Civil Works

Any in water improvement in berthing areas in such port pursuant to a channel widening or deepening
